title: Architectural Model, 1993
medium: Pear, walnut, satin wood, and other woods
signed: Signed, at center top of base: "19 David/Linley 93"
provenance: 1993: Eugene V. and Clare Thaw purchased directly from David Linley shop, London; 2013: acquired by Museum
creditline: Gift of Eugene V. and Clare E. Thaw
description: Model with openwork columns in cross shape on steps, supporting round colonnade on a second tier with spire above
justification: David Linley, the professional name of David Armstrong-Jones, Lord Linley, is one of Britain's best known furniture maker-designers. Hespecializes in high quality and sophisticated combinations of materials in furniture and other designs that reference history but are firmly contemporary.&nbsp; A skilled practitioner of inlay and of architectural design applied to decorative arts objects, he caters to collectors of many periods.&nbsp; While his start in 1985&nbsp;may have been smoothed by being the son of Princess Margaret and Lord Snowdon, he was very quick to make his mark through top level designs and execution, leading to a significant influence.&nbsp;&nbsp;This model shows both architectural liveliness combined with very refined turning and carving of the elements used.&nbsp; Linley is a designer who belongs in the top rank of contemporary furniture collections.

tombstone.epitaph: Architectural Model, 1993.Pear, walnut, satin wood, and other woods. Gift of Eugene V. and Clare E. Thaw. 2013-3-3.
